Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Novel Experiential Learning Toy Teaching Robotics and Automation to K-12 Students
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project is to raise awareness and enthusiasm for Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) education among young children through experiential learning enabled by novel and interactive robotic toys. U.S. Department of Labor's recent survey reports that only 5% of U.S. workers are employed in science and engineering fields, yet they are responsible for more than 50% of the sustained economic expansion. Over the past few decades the U.S. contribution to the number of scientists and engineers worldwide has reduced from 40% to 15%. Interestingly, there is a high interest among young students for the STEM fields but approximately 40% of them end up switching to non-STEM careers by the time they graduate from college - according to the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology. This project brings a radical change in this trend by aptly stimulating the curiosity and challenging the intelligence, the key catalysts for continued interest, in K-12 students. Through innovative and intelligent hardware and software modules, this project delivers an enhanced learning experience on next generation robotics and automation technologies in the classroom as well as at home, leading towards a much richer and secure prospect for the future tax payers.

This SBIR Phase I project develops an interactive and reconfigurable robotics-learning system comprised of smart positioning modules and interconnects. The key innovations include: a zero nuts-and-bolts architecture for quick and easy system setup, distributed artificial intelligence for interactive plug-n-play operations, and personalized gaming and learning feature to engage different age groups, experience levels, and study areas. This gaming and learning system aids in understanding various concepts of new age manufacturing, shaped by rapidly evolving economic constraints, including but not limited to: challenges in flexible/lean manufacturing for low cost and rapid turnaround production; effects of source agnostic automation, where robots/tools from different manufacturers are combined, on overall manufacturing metrics; and difficulties associated with robot cooperative control with limited feedback in complex operations. Such knowledge, gained through hands-on learning, better prepares the future scientists and engineers to not only adapt in the highly demanding manufacturing environment of the future but also explore innovative solutions to complex technical problems. This project envisions to significantly surpass the learning experience offered by contemporary educational toys, including passive building sets, jigsaw puzzles, rule-based interactive toys and so on, by delivering a highly immersed, actively encouraging, and truly exploratory experience for the makers of tomorrow.

POR.DRECONTENT:
TechComb LLC is a technology acceleration company specializing in the development and marketing of innovative technology products in domestic markets. The NSF SBIR Phase I project titled “A Novel Experiential Learning Toy Teaching Robotics and Automation to K-12 Students” resulted in prototyping a product that offers a unique combination of robotic gaming and learning experiences. Target audience for this product come from a wide range of market segments including K-12 schools, community colleges, universities, museums, professional training firms, as well as parents. Two primary constituents of the product, called as “Build-Teach-Play robot or BTPbot” and “STEM Learning Activity Board or SLAB” allow educators to disseminate knowledge in a more interactive way, students to visualize theoretical models in real world settings, and young children to engage in games based on robotic automation, thus promoting STEM awareness and acceptance at an early age, which is extremely crucial in the workforce development for the return of sustainable manufacturing to the U.S.

 

BTPbot features a set of intelligent robotic modules that allow the kids to build their personal construction robot, teach it to perform various object manipulator tasks, and play solo and team-based games. SLAB supplements the BTPbot’s appeal by offering an adaptive and positive reinforcement based learning gameboard with fun-oriented audio-visual interaction to play games, such as Tic-Tac-Toe, Ladders, Alphabets, Numbers and many more, with physical game pieces, thereby boosting a child’s cognitive as well as fine motor skills. The technology relies on self-motivation to learn difficult-to-master science and engineering concepts. The intrinsic motivation comes from five main sources:

(a)    skill adaptation – the learning curve to use the game hardware is short, so the user can quickly dive in to the fun-driven applications

(b)    Task identity – the carefully selected user-controlled tasks offer a rich perception to complex underlying engineering principles

(c)    Task significance – as a part of the post-game reporting feature the user activities are related to real world problems for easy correlation and understanding

(d)    Autonomy – the completely self-paced, personalized experience offers the user a sense of being in control of his/her own learning

(e)    Feedback – the reward-based system provides tangible feedback on the user’s performance in an encouraging way that inspires the user to better his/her approach next time

 

The BTPbot takes a significant burden off the educators at the front end of delivering the technical content as well as at the back end of assessing performance and tracking progress. As a highly effective teachers’ aid in STEM education the BTPbot finds its way to the 21st century classrooms in K-12 and beyond.

 

During the NSF SBIR Phase I funding period the company studied potential market for the product, interviewed different categories of stake holders, conducted hardware and software feasibility studies for the BTPbot and SLAB, prototyped a user-friendly design for the product, and developed introductory mobile app for the product. In addition to the aforementioned technical activities, the company also engaged in multiple outreach activities to disseminate the technology’s usefulness to potential stake holders and STEM education practitioners.

 

Through this product, TechComb LLC seeks to bring hands-on learning technology that enables students and educators to analyze and solve real-world problems in the classroom. The company believes that doing is the best form of learning and it is committed to meeting the ever-growing needs for quality education tools, preparing the young generation for the future STEM career fields. TechComb LLC’s product line envisions to significantly surpass the learning experience offered by contemporary educational toys, including passive building sets, jigsaw puzzles, rule-based interactive toys and so on, by delivering a highly immersed, actively encouraging, and truly exploratory experience for the makers of tomorrow.
